Notification Title: Coastal Flood Statement (Southern QN, BK, SI)
Email Body:
Notification issued 10/1/16 at 5:17 AM. The National Weather Service has issued a Coastal Flood Statement for Staten Island, Brooklyn and Southern Queens from 8:00 AM to 10:00 AM today, 10/1. The affected area includes the South Shore Bays of Nassau, Queens and Brooklyn. Tidal departures of 1-3/4  feet above normal are expected.

During a Coastal Flood Advisory, minor flooding of the most vulnerable shore roads and/or properties is possible. Coastal residents should be alert for later statements and take action to protect property.

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/.

Notification Title: Three Alarm Fire - 102nd Street & Atlantic Avenue (QN)
Email Body:
Notification issued 10/1/16 at 12:39 AM. Emergency personnel are on the scene of a three alarm fire located at 102nd Street and Atlantic Avenue in Queens. Expect smoke, traffic delays, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

Notification issued 9/30/16 at 7:43 AM. New York City is experiencing intermittent wind gusts in excess of 40 MPH. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. 

To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. 

If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. For the latest weather information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

The affected locations may include low lying areas along the New York Harbor, tidally affected portions of the Northeastern New Jersey, and along the South Shore of Western and Central Long Island. Tidal departures of 1 1/2 - 2 feet above normal levels are expected. During a Coastal Flood Advisory, minor flooding of the most vulnerable shore roads and/or properties is possible. Coastal residents should be alert for later statements and take action to protect property. For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 9/20/16 at 3:00 PM. Weather permitting, the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will spray adulticide to key mosquito breeding locations in residential areas of Brooklyn on Wednesday, 9/21, between the hours of 10:00 PM and 6:00 AM the following morning, 9/22. Adulticide will be sprayed from a truck in parts of the following ZIP codes: 11203, 11210, 11212, 11213, 11225, 11226, 12229, 11233, 11234, 11235, and 11236. Spraying is intended to reduce the number of mosquitoes and the risk of Zika and West Nile viruses.

In case of inclement weather, application will be delayed until Thursday, 9/22, during the same hours.

For more details, http://on.nyc.gov/2bqbNVN, http://i.imgur.com/7L8KBqM.jpg, or call 3-1-1.

- MTA M5, M7 Northbound, M23, and X10, X17, X27, X28, and X1 Manhattan-bound buses are detoured around the area

Please visit www.mta.info for updates.

Notification issued 9/18/16 at 4:25 PM. NYPD controlled detonation activity will occur today near Rodmans Neck in The Bronx. The activity is scheduled to take place between approximately 4:30 PM and 6:30 PM. The effects of this routine activity may be heard in nearby neighborhoods.
Notification issued 9/18/16 at 2:00 PM. The prior flooding issue at Pre-K site PK812 has been resolved. Starting tomorrow, 9/19, staff and students will return to 411 46th Street in Brooklyn.

Notification issued 9/18/16 at 11:48 AM. Update: Due to ongoing emergency operations as a result of last night's explosion in the neighborhood of Chelsea in Manhattan, the following traffic restrictions and transit disruptions remain in place:

- West 23rd Street is closed in both directions between 5th and 7th Avenues
- Northbound traffic is restricted on 6th Avenue at 14th Street
- Southbound traffic is restricted on 7th Avenue at 34th Street
- All cross-town (eastbound and westbound) traffic is restricted from West 14th Street to West 32nd street between 5th Avenue and 8th Avenue
- NYCT E, F, 1, and 2 Trains are bypassing 23rd Street and 28th Street stations in both directions
- MTA M5, M7 Northbound, M23, and X10, X17, X27, X28, and X1 Manhattan-bound buses are detoured around the area

Please visit www.mta.info for updates.

Residents are being allowed access to the area with a police escort only. If you require access to the affected areas, please bring identification for proof of residence o

Notification issued 9/18/16 at 3:40 AM. Due to the earlier explosion in Chelsea, crosstown traffic eastbound and westbound is closed from West 14th Street to West 32nd Street, from 5th Avenue to 8th Avenue in Manhattan. These closures are in effect until further notice.
Alert issued 9/18/16 at 2:40 AM. UPDATE: The suspicious device on West 27th Street in Chelsea has been safely removed by the NYPD Bomb Squad.

Alert issued 9/18/16 at 12:34 AM. ALERT: NYPD is requesting residents on West 27th Street between 6th Avenue and 7th Avenue in Manhattan to stay away from windows facing 27th Street until they clear a suspicious package.

Notification issued 9/17/16 at 11:10 PM. Due to an explosion at West 23rd Street between 6th Avenue and 7th Avenue, the following subway lines are impacted:

The F Line is suspended between Delancey Street (MN) and 21st Street/Queensbridge (QN).

Selected E service will operate via the R Line to Whitehall Street to be turned back north.

The 1 Line is suspended between South Ferry and 34th Street in both directions.

The 2 Line is suspended between 34th Street and Chambers Street (MN) in both directions.

Selected southbound 1 and 2 service will be turned at 34th Street.

The following street closures to vehicular and pedestrian traffic are in effect:

Northbound traffic on 6th Avenue at 14th Street, southbound traffic on 7th Avenue at 34th Street, and 23rd Street is closed in both directions between 5th Avenue and 7th Avenue.

There are no impacts to Penn Station, Amtrak, LIRR or NJT service.

Please avoid the area.

For more info, visit www.weather.gov/nyc. During a severe thunderstorm, be prepared to potentially lose power. Charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, & turn refrigerators/freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances & keep refrigerator/freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power & have a disability or access needs or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) & need immediate assistance, dial 9-1-1. Email Body:
Notification issued 9/13/16 at 9:07 PM. Emergency personnel are on the scene of a three alarm fire located at Greene and Broome Streets (MN). Expect smoke, traffic delays, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

Notification issued 9/6/16 at 9:00 AM. The National Weather Service has issued a Coastal Flood Statement for Staten Island from 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM today, 9/6. The affected area includes the low lying coastal areas around Staten Island. Tidal departures of 1.5 to 2.0 feet above astronomical tides are expected.

During a coastal flood event, minor flooding of the most vulnerable shore roads and/or adjacent properties is possible due to the height of the storm tide.

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 9/6/16 at 8:20 AM. New York City is experiencing intermittent wind gusts in excess of 40 MPH. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. 

To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. 

If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. For the latest weather information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 9/4/16 at 7:00 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Tropical Storm Warning for New York City until further notice. New Yorkers should take actions ahead of the storm to prepare for high winds, minor-to-moderate coastal flooding, rain, life-threatening rip tides, and high surf.  The National Weather Service is currently forecasting sustained winds of 20-30 mph with the potential for gusts up to 50 mph for the NYC area beginning as early as Sunday, and possibly extending through Tuesday evening. High winds can bring down trees and power lines and can turn unsecured objects into dangerous projectiles. When winds reach tropical storm levels, NYC area bridges may implement speed and vehicle restrictions. New Yorkers should expect potential restrictions Sunday evening through Tuesday. Due to life-threatening rip tides, NYC beaches are closed to swimming, surfing, and bathing on Monday, September 5, 2016. Notification Title: Tropical Storm Warning & Storm Surge Watch (CW)
Email Body: Notification issued 9/3/16 at 8:22 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Tropical Storm Warning and Storm Surge Watch for New York City until further notice. New Yorkers should take actions ahead of the storm to prepare for high winds, minor-to-moderate coastal flooding, rain, life-threatening rip tides, and high surf. The National Weather Service is currently forecasting sustained winds of 35-45 mph with the potential for gusts up to 60 mph for the NYC area beginning as early as Sunday, and possibly extending through Tuesday evening. High winds can bring down trees and power lines and can turn unsecured objects into dangerous projectiles. When winds reach tropical storm levels, NYC area bridges may implement speed and vehicle restrictions. New Yorkers should expect potential restrictions Sunday evening through Tuesday. Due to life-threatening rip tides, NYC beaches are closed to swimming, surfing, and bathing on Sunday, September 4, 2016. Prepare for flooding: If you live in a flood-susceptible area,

Notification Title: Tropical Storm Watch and Storm Surge Watch - 9/2 (CW)
Email Body:
Alert issued 9/2/16 at 12:25 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Tropical Storm Watch for New York City. A Tropical Storm Watch is issued 48 hours in advance of the possible onset of tropical-storm-force winds, which include sustained wind speeds of 39mph-74mph. 

The National Weather Service has also issued a Storm Surge Watch for coastal areas of New York City until further notice. The combination of strong winds, dangerous storm surge and high tide may cause normally dry areas to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline within the next 48 hours.

During a Tropical Storm Watch and a Storm Surge Watch, prepare your home and review your plan for evacuation in case a Hurricane or Tropical Storm Warning is issued. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1.

For the latest weather information, visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification Title: NYC Emergency Management Monitors Hurricane Hermine (CW)
Email Body:
Notification issued 9/1/16 at 5:25 PM. The New York City Emergency Management Department is closely monitoring Hurricane Hermine and the possible effects the storm may have on the City as it moves towards the north. The storm is expected to be near the Florida coast tonight or early tomorrow morning before making its way up the east coast. 

While there is significant uncertainty in the track, instensity, and speed of the storm, possible impacts to the City include strong rip currents, high surf, coastal flooding, heavy rain, and strong winds. 

For the latest weather information, visit www.weather.gov/nyc. For more information and preparedness tips, visit http://on.nyc.gov/2bHDCsg.

Notification issued 9/1/2016 4:00 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Flood Advisory for Queens until 5:45 PM. Minor flooding and overflowing of poor drainage areas is possible. 

Do not drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the roadway. The water depth may be too great to allow your car to cross safely. Move to higher ground.

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Weather permitting, the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will spray adulticide to key mosquito breeding locations in residential areas of Manhattan and Queens on Wednesday, 8/17, between the hours of 10:00 PM and 6:00 AM the following morning, 8/18. Adulticide will be sprayed from a truck in parts of the following ZIP codes: 10032, 10033, 10034, 10039, 10040, 11354, 11355, 11358, 11361, 11364, 11365, 11367 and 11368. Notification issued 8/13/16 at 8:53 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Watch for New York City until 1:00 AM Sunday. Strong winds and heavy rain are possible. 

A Severe Thunderstorm Watch means conditions are favorable for severe thunderstorms to occur in and close to the watch area. Persons within these areas should be on the lookout for threatening weather conditions and listen for later statements and possible warnings. Exercise caution when walking, driving, or biking. 

Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaini

Alert issued 8/13/16 at 10:45 AM. Con Edison is asking customers in some Brooklyn neighborhoods to conserve energy while company crews work to repair equipment problems. Con Edison has also reduced voltage by 5 percent in those areas as a precaution to protect equipment and maintain service as repairs are made.

The area includes the following neighborhoods: Sheepshead Bay, Marine Park, Gerritsen Beach, Midwood, Flatbush, and East Flatbush.

Company crews are working now to repair the problem. Con Edison has asked customers in these areas not to use energy-intensive appliances such as washers, dryers, microwaves and, if not needed for health or medical reasons, air conditioners, until the equipment problems are resolved.

Customers can report outages and check service restoration status at www.coned.com or by calling 1-800-75-CONED (1-800-752-6633). For more energy tips, visit www.coned.com.

Spraying is intended to reduce the number of mosquitoes and the risk of Zika and West Nile viruses.  Adulticide will be sprayed from a truck and will be conducted in parts of the following ZIP codes in the Brooklyn and  Queens: 11207, 11208, 11236, 11239 ,11103, 11105, 11369, 11370, 11371, 11372 and 11377.

In case of inclement weather, application will be delayed until Wednesday, 8/10, during the same hours.

For more details, go to http://on.nyc.gov/1rGzdLi, http://bit.ly/2aMsSGl, or call 3-1-1.

To view this message in American Sign Language (ASL), Arabic, Bengali, Chinese, French, Haitian Creole, Italian, Korean, Polish, Russian, Spanish, Urdu, or Yiddish, please visit: http://on.nyc.gov/1mwJI15.

Notification Title: Mosquito Larviciding - August 8 - 10th (SI, BK, QN, BX)
Email Body:
Notification issued 8/7/16 at 12:00 PM. Weather permitting, the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will aerially apply larvicide to key mosquito breeding areas in non-residential areas (mainly marshes and other large wetlands) between 6 AM and 7 PM on Monday 8/8, Tuesday 8/9, and Wednesday 8/10, to reduce the number of mosquitoes and the risk of Zika and West Nile viruses. A helicopter will be used for this event. The larviciding will be conducted in parts of the following ZIP codes in the Bronx, Staten Island, Brooklyn and Queens: 10303, 10311, 10314, 10306, 10308, 10309, 10312, 10305, 10310, 11229, 11234, 11239, 11362, 11363, 11354, 11356, 11357, 11691, 11629, 11413, 11422, 11355, 11365, 10464, 10475, and 10465.  

In case of inclement weather, the larviciding will be rescheduled to occur from 6AM - 7PM on August 9th, 10th, and 11th.

For details, go to http://on.nyc.gov/1rGzdLi, http://bit.ly/2bbZ7ji, http://i.imgur.com/CJuUdjf.jpg or call 3-1-1.

To view this message in American Sign Langua

Notification Title: Planned Mass Transit Closure - PATH Train Weekend Service Disruptions - 8/9 - 12/19 (MN)
Email Body:
Notification issued 8/5/16 at 3:00 PM. Due to federally mandated safety and service upgrades, all PATH train stations in Manhattan  will be closed on the weekends beginning August 6 through December 19, 2016. The closure will begin on Saturdays at 12:10 AM until Mondays at 5:00 AM.

PATH weekend shuttle bus service will be available for pick - up and drop - off at various locations. For service to New Jersey, take a NYC Subway train to the World Train Center or use the free weekend shuttle bus service that operates between the World Trade Center and 29th Street. 

For more information and a map of shuttle bus service locations please visit: http://i.imgur.com/DrmTkAu.png.

Notification Title: Planned Road Closures - Summer Streets Series - 8/6, 8/13, 8/20 (MN)
Email Body:
Notification issued 8/5/16 at 3:00 PM. Due to the Summer Streets series, various street closures will be in effect in Manhattan from 7:00 AM to 1:00 PM August 6th, August 13th, and August 20th.


For more information please go to: http://on.nyc.gov/1jPOgNG.

Notification issued 8/5/16 at 12:35 PM. Emergency personnel are on the scene of a transformer fire located at Centre Street and White Street in Manhattan. Expect smoke, traffic delays, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

The NYPD has issued a Silver Alert for the disappearance of Lloyd Garcia, a 73-year-old Hispanic male of the Jamaica section of Queens.

The missing was last seen on 8/2 at approximately 8:00 AM in the area of Sean Bell Way and 95th Avenue(QN).

He is described as 5'9'', 170 lbs., with gray hair, brown eyes, thin build and a beard. He was last seen wearing a dark green t - shirt, gray jeans and black boots.

Notification Title: Flash Flood Warning (BK, QN, MN, BX)
Email Body:
Alert issued 7/31/16 at 9:40 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Flash Flood Warning for Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan, and the Bronx until 12:30 AM. Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of urban areas, highways, streets, and underpasses as well as other drainage areas and low lying spots. Do not drive your vehicle into areas where the water covers the roadway. The water depth may be too great to allow your car to cross safely. Move to higher ground.

For the latest information, visit: http://www.weather.gov/nyc.

If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1.

Residential oil tanks in flooded basements may leak or rupture. If you suspect an oil spill in your home, call the NYSDEC Spill Hotline at (800) 457-7362. For more information on home heating oil spills, visit http://www.dec.ny.gov/chemical/8428.html#response or call 311.

To view this message in American Sign Language

Do not drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the roadway. The water depth may be too great to allow your car to cross safely. Move to higher ground.

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Email Body: Notification issued 7/25/16 at 8:02 PM.  Following an earlier suspension, all LIRR service has been restored with residual delays.

Notification issued 7/25/16 at 7:40 PM.  Due to flooding conditions, all westbound lanes of the Belt Parkway towards Brooklyn are closed between Flatbush Avenue and Knapp Street.  Consider alternate routes and allow additional travel time.

Notification Title: LIRR Suspension  - All Service Between Penn, Atlantic, & Jamaica (CW)
Email Body: Notification issued 7/25/16 at 7:00 PM. Due to weather-related signal problems, all Long Island Railroad service between Penn Station, Atlantic Terminal, and Jamaica is suspended in both directions. NYC Transit is cross-honoring at Jamaica (Sutphin - Archer) for service to Penn. Additionally, the Port Washington and West Hempstead Branches remain suspended, and there is limited service on the Long Beach Branch. For updates, visit www.mta.info.

Notification Title: LIRR Suspension - Eastbound Service from Penn & Atlantic (CW)
Email Body: Notification issued 7/25/16 at 6:45 PM. Due to weather-related signal trouble at Jamaica, all eastbound Long Island Railroad service is suspended out of Penn Station and Atlantic Terminal. NYC Transit is cross-honoring fares at 34th Street for E Train service to Jamaica. www.mta.info.
Notification issued 7/25/16 at 6:20 PM. Due to weather related signal problems, Long Island Railroad service is suspended on the West Hempstead Branch in both directions. www.mta.info.

Notification issued 7/25/16 at 6:00 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Heat Advisory for New York City for tomorrow, 7/26, from 12:00 PM until 6:00 PM. The Heat Advisory for today, 7/25, also remains in effect until 8:00 PM tonight. 

These conditions are dangerous to health. Avoid strenuous activity. People without air conditioning, older adults, and people with chronic health conditions are most at risk. Cooling centers will be open. 

For the latest weather information, please visit: www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 7/25/16 at 5:16 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for New York City until 5:45 PM. Strong winds & heavy rain is expected. For more info, visit www.weather.gov/nyc. During a severe thunderstorm, be prepared to potentially lose power. Charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, & turn refrigerators/freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances & keep refrigerator/freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power & have a disability or access needs or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) & need immediate assistance, dial 9-1-1.

Alert issued 7/25/16 at 5:07 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Flash Flood Warning for Queens, Brooklyn, and Staten Island until 8:00 PM. Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of urban areas, highways, streets, and underpasses as well as other drainage areas and low lying spots. Do not drive your vehicle into areas where the water covers the roadway. The water depth may be too great to allow your car to cross safely. Move to higher ground.

For the latest information, visit: http://www.weather.gov/nyc.

If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1.

Residential oil tanks in flooded basements may leak or rupture. If you suspect an oil spill in your home, call the NYSDEC Spill Hotline at (800) 457-7362. For more information on home heating oil spills, visit http://www.dec.ny.gov/chemical/8428.html#response or call 311.

Notification issued 7/25/16 at 12:50 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Watch for NYC until 8:00 PM tonight. Strong winds and heavy rain are possible. 

A Severe Thunderstorm Watch means conditions are favorable for severe thunderstorms to occur in and close to the watch area. Persons within these areas should be on the lookout for threatening weather conditions and listen for later statements and possible warnings. Exercise caution when walking, driving, or biking. 

Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equip

Notification Title: Mosquito Larviciding - July 26-July 28 (SI, BK, QN, BX)
Email Body:
Notification issued 7/25/16 at 12:00 PM. Weather permitting, the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will aerially apply larvicide to key mosquito breeding locations in non-residential areas (mainly marshes and other large wetlands) between 6:00 AM and 7:00 PM on Tuesday 7/26, Wednesday 7/27, and Thursday 7/28, to reduce the number of mosquitoes and the risk of Zika and West Nile viruses. A helicopter will be used for this event. The larviciding will be conducted in parts of the following ZIP codes in Staten Island, Brooklyn, Queens and The Bronx: 10303, 10305, 10306, 10308, 10309, 10310, 10311, 10312, 10314, 10464, 10465, 10475, 11229, 11234, 11239, 11354, 11355, 11356, 11357, 11362, 11363, 11413, 11422, 11691, and 11692.

In case of inclement weather, the larviciding will be rescheduled to occur 6:00 AM - 7:00 PM on Friday 7/29, Saturday 7/30, and Sunday 7/31.

For more details, go to http://on.nyc.gov/1rGzdLi, http://i.imgur.com/U9vUOlm.jpg, or call 3-1-1.

To view this message in American Si

Notification 7/24/16 at 3:00 PM. Opening fire hydrants without spray caps is illegal, wasteful and dangerous. Illegally opened hydrants can lower water pressure and put lives at risk if there is a fire. Children can also be at risk, because the powerful force of an open hydrant without a spray cap can cause serious injury. New Yorkers should call 3-1-1 to report open hydrants. Hydrants can be opened legally with a City-approved spray cap which can be obtained by an adult, 18 or over, free of charge, at local firehouses.

Alert issued 7/23/16 at 11:35 PM. Con Edison is asking customers in sections of Riverdale and Washington Heights to conserve energy while company crews work to repair equipment problems. Con Edison has also reduced voltage by 8 percent in those areas as a precaution to protect equipment and maintain service as repairs are made. Company crews are working now to repair the problem. Con Edison has asked customers in these areas not to use energy-intensive appliances such as washers, dryers, microwaves and, if not needed for health or medical reasons, air conditioners, until the equipment problems are resolved. 

Customers can report outages and check service restoration status at www.coned.com or by calling 1-800-75-CONED (1-800-752-6633). For more energy tips, visit www.coned.com.

Notification Title: Missing Vulnerable Alert - Dwight Rowe M/B/24 (CW)
Email Body:
Alert issued 7/19/16 at 3:38 PM.

The Suffolk County Police Department has issued a Missing Vulnerable Adult Alert for the disappearance of Dwight Rowe, a 24-year-old, Black male with autism from North Amityville, NY.  

He is described as 5'2'', 183  lbs., with black hair and brown eyes. He was last seen wearing a black t-shirt with an orange tank top underneath, camouflage colored shorts, slippers and was carrying a lunchbox .

The missing was last seen at his home on Silverpine Drive in North Amityville at approximately 7:00 AM today,  Tuesday July 19, 2016.

Photo of missing can be seen here: http://i.imgur.com/pOcBpNY.png

If seen, please call Suffolk County Police Department at (631) 852-6000 or 911.

To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. Notification Title: Three Alarm Fire - West 42nd Street and 11th Avenue (MN)
Email Body:
Notification issued 7/7/16 at 9:08 AM. Emergency personnel are on the scene of a three alarm fire located at West 42nd Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan. Expect smoke, traffic delays, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

Notification Title: Mosquito Larviciding - July 7 - 9 (SI, BK, QN, BX)
Email Body:
Notification issued 7/6/16 at 12:00 PM. Weather permitting, the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will aerially apply larvicide to key mosquito breeding areas in non-residential areas (mainly marshes and other large wetlands) between 6:00 AM and 7:00 PM on Thursday 7/7, Friday 7/8, and Saturday 7/9, to reduce the number of mosquitoes and the risk of Zika and West Nile viruses. A helicopter will be used for this event. The larviciding will be conducted in parts of the following ZIP codes in Staten Island, Brooklyn, Queens and The Bronx: 10303, 10305, 10306, 10308, 10309, 10310, 10311, 10312, 10314, 10464, 10465, 10475, 11229, 11234, 11239, 11354, 11355, 11365, 11357, 11362, 11363, 11365, 11413, 11422, 11691, & 11692.

In case of inclement weather, the larviciding will be rescheduled to occur from 6:00 AM - 7:00 PM on July 8th, 9th, and 10th. 

For more details, go to http://on.nyc.gov/1rGzdLi, http://i.imgur.com/IsZ1AG6.png, or call 3-1-1.

Notification issued 7/6/16 at 12:45 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a heat advisory for New York City in effect from 1:00 PM today, 7/6, until 8:00 PM tomorrow, 7/7. The heat index is expected to be near or above 95 degrees through tomorrow evening. High heat indices are dangerous to health, avoid strenuous activity. People without air conditioning, older adults, and people with chronic health conditions are most at risk. Cooling centers will be open today, 7/6, 1:00 PM  8:00 PM and tomorrow, 7/7, beginning at 8:00 AM. In addition, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has issued an Air Quality Health Advisory for New York City for today, 7/6, from 11:00 AM to 11:00 PM. Active children, adults, and people with lung disease such as asthma, should reduce prolonged or heavy exertion outdoors. 

For cooling center locations & hours, or for more information on avoiding heat illness, please visit: http://www.nyc.gov/beattheheat, http://on.nyc.gov/29n4FYL
 or call 3-1-1.

Notification issued 7/1/16 at 9:18 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for Queens until 10:00 PM and an extension of the already issued Severe Thunderstorm Warning for The Bronx and Manhattan until 10 PM. Strong winds and heavy rain are expected.

Info: http://www.weather.gov/nyc.

During a severe thunderstorm, be prepared to potentially lose power. Charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by the outage, turn off all appliances, avoid downed and hanging power lines, and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1.

Alert issued 7/1/16 at 2:00 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Tornado Watch for the New York City area until 10:00 PM. A Tornado Watch indicates that conditions are favorable for a tornado to form. A tornado has not yet developed or been reported.

A Tornado Watch means conditions are favorable for a tornado to occur in and close to the watch area. Persons within these areas should be on the lookout for threatening weather conditions and listen for later statements and possible warnings. Exercise caution when walking, driving, or biking. 

Tornadoes can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or

DATE CORRECTION: Notification issued 6/23/16 at 10:17 AM. Weather permitting, the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will aerially apply larvicide to key mosquito breeding areas in non-residential areas (mainly marshes and other large wetlands) between 6 AM and 7 PM on Friday  6/24, Saturday 6/25, and Sunday  6/26, to reduce the number of mosquitoes and the risk of Zika and West Nile viruses. A helicopter will be used for this event. The larviciding will be conducted in parts of the following ZIP codes in Staten Island, Brooklyn, Queens and The Bronx: 10303, 10305, 10306, 10308, 10309, 10310, 10311, 10312, 10314, 10464, 10465, 10475, 11229, 11234, 11239, 11354, 11355, 11356, 11357, 11362, 11363, 11365, 11413, 11422, 11691, & 11692.

In case of inclement weather, the larviciding will be rescheduled to occur from 6AM - 7PM on June 25, 26, and 27th.

For more details, go to http://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/health/health-topics/west-nile-virus-spray.page or  http://i.imgur.com/BbqvIKt.jpg, or call 3-1-1.

Notification Title: Silver Alert - Doris J. Dunbar F/B/76 (CW)
Email Body:
Silver Alert issued 6/14/16 at 9:10 PM.  The NYPD has issued a Silver Alert for the disappearance of Doris J. Dunbar, a 76-year-old Black female with dementia.

Ms. Dunbar was last seen 6/14 at approximately 11:05 AM in the Citadel Rehab & Nursing Center, located at 3400 Cannon Place (BX).  However, she may have traveled to one of the NYCHA Marcy Houses, located 552 Marcy Avenue (BK).

Ms. Dunbar is described as 5'4'', 120 lbs., with gray hair and brown eyes. She was last seen wearing a black hat, brown hooded sweatshirt, pink sweatpants and black sneakers.  Ms. Dunbar does not have identification and may be in need of medical attention.

A photo is attached here: http://i.imgur.com/LqkmBrJ.png

If seen, please call 9-1-1

Notification issued 6/12/16 at 12:15 PM. New York City is experiencing intermittent wind gusts in excess of 40 MPH. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. 

To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. 

If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. For the latest weather information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification Title: Mosquito Larviciding - June 9 -11th (SI, BK, QN, BX)
Email Body:
Notification issued 6/8/16 at 3:00 PM. Weather permitting, the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will aerially apply larvicide to key mosquito breeding areas in non-residential areas (mainly marshes and other large wetlands) between 6 AM and 7 PM on Thursday 6/9, Friday 6/10, and Saturday 6/11, to reduce the number of mosquitoes and the risk of Zika and West Nile viruses. A helicopter will be used for this event. The larviciding will be conducted in parts of the following ZIP codes in Staten Island, Brooklyn, Queens and The Bronx: 10303, 10305, 10306, 10308, 10309, 10310, 10311, 10312, 10314, 10464, 10465, 10475, 11229, 11234, 11239, 11354, 11355, 11356, 11357, 11362, 11363, 11365, 11413, 11422, 11691, & 11692.

In case of inclement weather, the larviciding will be rescheduled to occur from 6AM - 7PM on June 10, 11, and 12th. 

For more details, go to http://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/health/health-topics/west-nile-virus-spray.page, http://i.imgur.com/KNDRO02.png, or call 3-1-1.

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 6/5/16 at 6:30 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for New York City until 7:15 PM. Strong winds & heavy rain is expected. For more info, visit www.weather.gov/nyc. During a severe thunderstorm, be prepared to potentially lose power. Charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, & turn refrigerators/freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances & keep refrigerator/freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power & have a disability or access needs or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) & need immediate assistance, dial 9-1-1.

To view this message in American Sign Language (ASL), Arabic, Bengali, Chinese, French, Haitian Creole, Italian, Korean, Polish, Russian, Spanish, Urdu, or Yiddish, please visit: http://on.nyc.gov/1S66E3w.

Notification 6/5/16 at 3:20 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Watch for NYC until 10:00 PM on 6/5. Dangerous lightning, heavy rain, and strong winds are possible. A Severe Thunderstorm Watch means conditions are favorable for severe thunderstorms to occur in an close to the watch area. Persons within these areas should be on the lookout for threatening weather conditions and listen for later statements and possible warnings. Exercise caution when walking, driving, or biking. 
 
The safest place to be during a thunderstorm is indoors as dangerous lightning can occur. 
 
Do not use the telephone, electrical appliances, showers, sinks, or any object, machine, or device connected to the buildings electrical wiring or plumbing systems. If lightning strikes the building, the current will likely flow through the electrical wiring or water pipes and you could receive a fatal shock.
 
If you are caught outside during a thunderstorm:
- Stay away from tall, isolated trees or other

Notification Title: Severe Weather - The Governors Ball Cancellation (MN)

Email Body:
Notification issued 6/4/16 at 6:30 PM. New York City Emergency Management has issued a Weather Advisory for Sunday, June 5, 2016. According to the National Weather Service, heavy rain and thunderstorms are expected for the New York City area on Sunday. The heaviest period of rain and thunderstorms is expected Sunday afternoon and evening, with isolated downpours, small hail, damaging wind gusts, and flash flooding possible. New Yorkers are advised to stay indoors during periods of severe weather.

The National Weather Service has advised of the possibility of wind gusts in excess of 30 MPH. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at high speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all app

Notification Title: Fleet Week 2016 - Various Demonstrations - Hudson, Citi Field, Intrepid Pier (MN/QN)
Email Body:
Notification issued 5/29/16 at 3:00 PM. In conjunction with Fleet Week 2016, various military flyover activities will take place tomorrow, May 30th. 

At 12:00 PM, The U.S. Navy will conduct a flyover involving four FA - 18's east up the Hudson past the Intrepid, to support the Intrepid Memorial Day Ceremony.

At approximately 12:55 PM, U.S. Navy Leap Frogs will conduct a parachute jump into Citi Field in Queens, prior to the NY Mets Game.
 
At approximately 1:00 PM, the U.S. Navy will conduct a flyover involving four FA - 18's prior to the NY Mets Game at Citi Field.

At 1:30 PM, The U.S Coast Guard will conduct a search & rescue demonstration over the water in the vicinity of Pier 86 - The Intrepid Air & Space Museum in Manhattan. Weather permitting, the demonstration will consist of one swimmer exiting a U.S. Coast Guard helicopter to perform a rescue demonstration. 

For more info, please visit www.fleetweeknewyork.com.

To view this message in American Sign Language (ASL), Arabic, Bengali, Ch

Notification issued 5/27/16 at 3:05 PM. On Saturday, May 28, the Breitling Jet Team will conduct a photo mission beginning at 5:00 PM over various parts of NYC. The aircraft will travel westbound from Long Island over the water near the south shores of Queens and Brooklyn before turning and navigating north over the Verrazano Bridge, continuing up the east side of the Hudson River to the Tappan Zee Bridge. From there, the aircraft will turn around and travel southbound over the west side of the Hudson River to the Verrazano Bridge, before traveling northbound up the east side of the Hudson River to finish their route. During this operation, the aircraft will fly at an altitude of approximately 1,500 - 2,000 feet. The rain date for the event is scheduled for Sunday, May 29, at 5:00 PM. A photo of the aircraft is available at http://bit.ly/25jxIRO.

Email Body:
Notification issued 5/24/16 at 3:30 PM. In honor of Fleet Week 2016, Fort Hamilton will conduct its annual Salute to Ships on Wednesday, May 25th. At approximately 11:50 AM, the parade of 14 ships will begin entering New York Harbor and will be passing under the Verrazano Bridge. For more info, please visit www.fleetweeknewyork.com.

Notification Title: Planned Road Closure & Diversion - Houston Street Overpass at FDR Drive (MN)
Email Body: Notification issued 5/20/16 at 12:00 PM. Due to the New York City Department of Transportation's rehabilitation of the Houston Street Overpass at FDR Drive in Manhattan, there will be a diversion of all northbound FDR Drive traffic under Houston Street beginning tomorrow, May 21, at 12:01 AM and continuing through Monday, May 23, at 5:00 AM. Motorists traveling northbound on FDR Drive will be directed to proceed on the adjacent ramp.  Motorists will be unable to enter or exit the northbound FDR Drive at Exit 5 (Houston Street). The pedestrian ramps that provide access to East River Park near Houston Street will be closed. Consider alternate routes and allow for additional travel time. http://imgur.com/a/SHIxa.

Notification issued 5/17/16 at 10:40 PM. Due to fire department activity at 118th Street and Park Avenue, Metro-North service is suspended to and from Grand Central Terminal. Customers should transfer to the subway to connect to trains at stations in the Bronx.

For the New Haven Line, take the 2 train to 233rd Street to connect to Woodlawn Metro-North Station. 

For the Harlem Line, take the 2 train to 241st Street to connect to the Wakefield Metro-North Station. 

For the Hudson Line, take the 4 train or the D train to 161st Street-Yankee Stadium to connect Metro-North's Yankees East 153rd Street Station, or the 1 train to 225 Street-Marble Hill. 

NYC Transit is cross-honoring Metro-North tickets at Grand Central and the Bronx stations.
For more information and updates, visit www.mta.info.

Notification Title: Three Alarm Fire - East 118th Street & Park Avenue (MN)
Email Body:
Notification issued 5/17/16 at 7:30 PM. Emergency personnel are on the scene of a three alarm fire located at East 118th Street and Park Avenue in Manhattan. Expect smoke, traffic delays, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

Notification issued 5/16/16 at 1:12 PM. New York City is experiencing intermittent wind gusts in excess of 40 MPH. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. For the latest weather information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 5/16/16 at 10:15 AM.  The National Weather Service has issued a statement for the elevated risk for the spread of brush fires in New York City today, May 16, until 7:00 PM this evening.

With relative humidity values dropping to 25-30 percent this afternoon combined with westerly winds gusting to 30-35 mph, an elevated risk for brush fires is created.  For more infomation, see the following link: https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/a/a.php?i=2889537

Notification Title: West Nile Virus Aerial Larviciding 5/12-5/14 (SI, BK, QN, BX)
Email Body: Notification issued 5/12/16 at 4:30 PM. Weather permitting, the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will aerially apply larvicide to key mosquito breeding areas in non-residential areas (mainly marshes and other large wetlands) between 6 AM and 7 PM on Thursday 5/12, Friday 5/13, and Saturday 5/14, to reduce the number of mosquitoes and the risk of Zika and West Nile viruses. A helicopter will be used for this event. The spraying will be conducted in parts of the following ZIP codes in Staten Island, Brooklyn, Queens and The Bronx: 10464, 10465, 10475, 11229, 11234, 11239, 11103, 11105, 11370, 11377, 11378, 11379, 11385, 11416, 11418, 11421, 10303, 10305, 10306, 10308, 10309, 10311, 10312, and 10314. For more details, go to http://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/health/health-topics/west-nile-virus-spray.page, http://i.imgur.com/IfY1UaU.png or call 3-1-1.

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 5/8/16 at 3:00 PM. The US Department of Homeland Security, in coordination with the MTA NYCT, will begin a study called Underground Transport Restoration on Monday, May 9. The airflow study will be conducted over a five-day window from May 9-13, 2016 in multiple subway stations in Midtown Manhattan and will consist of a single, 20-minute release period of a non-toxic, odorless gas beginning at 11:00 AM each day. During this release period, researchers will disperse low concentrations of harmless gas and particle tracers and then use these tracers to conduct sampling over a four-hour window after release.
Data from the study will help first responders to better understand how airborne contaminants can travel through the system and enable them to develop emergency responses based on the results. The processes and equipment used in this study pose no health risks to the public.
For more information, please visit: https://www.dhs.gov/publication/environmental-assessment-proposed-nyc-subway

Notification issued 5/8/16 at 2:13 PM. New York City is experiencing intermittent wind gusts in excess of 40 MPH. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. For the latest weather information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 4/30/16 at 3:00 PM. Multiple street closures will be in effect citywide on Sunday, May 1, 2016 from 2:00 AM to 6:00 PM, in support of the 2015 TD Five Boro Bike Tour, including a full closure of the lower level of the Staten Island bound Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. The upper level of the Verrazano Bridge will remain open in both directions throughout the event.  In addition, traffic exiting the Hugh L. Carey Tunnel (Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel) will be diverted to Hamilton Avenue between 9:00 AM and 3:30 PM. The ramp to the FDR Drive from the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge will be closed between 7:45 AM and 12:00 PM, with all Manhattan bound traffic exiting at 125th Street. For more information, please visit http://www.nycbikemaps.com/maps/five-boro-bike-tour-map/.

Email Body:

A Silver Alert has been issued for the disappearance of Marie Jean Brown, a 78-year-old black female from the area of East 38th Street and Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn.

Notification issued 4/21/16 at 11:25 AM. The National Weather Service has issued a Red Flag Warning for New York City and surrounding areas due to conditions favorable for rapid fire spread. The warning is in effect today, 4/21, to 6:00 PM.

A Red Flag Warning is issued when a combination of strong winds and dry conditions create a significantly elevated fire growth potential. Todays winds speeds will be 10-15 MPH with gusts up to 25 MPH and a relative humidity of mid to upper 20s. Exercise caution when using outdoor gas and charcoal grills. In addition, smokers should never carelessly discard cigarettes. Immediately report a brush fire to 9-1-1.

For the latest information please visit: http://www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 4/7/16 at 8:12 AM. The National Weather Service has issued a Wind Advisory for Brooklyn and Queens. The advisory is in effect today, 4/7, from 11:00 AM to 8:00 PM. The advisory has been issued for sustained winds of 30-40 MPH possible gusts of 50 MPH. 

During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. 

For the latest weather information visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification Title: Six Alarm Fire - Dekalb Avenue & Knickerbocker Avenue (BK)
Email Body: Notification issued 3/30/16 at 3:09 AM. Emergency personnel continue to operate on scene of what is now a six alarm fire located at Dekalb Avenue and Knickerbocker Avenue in the Brooklyn. Expect smoke, traffic delays, road closures, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

Notification issued 3/29/16 at 10:24 PM. Emergency personnel are on the scene of a three alarm fire located at Dekalb Avenue and Knickerbocker Avenue in Brooklyn. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

Notification issued 3/28/16 at 12:00 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Wind Advisory for NYC which is in effect from 5:00 PM 3/28 to 6:00 PM on Tuesday, 3/29. The advisory has been issued for sustained winds of 20-30 MPH with gusts up to 50 MPH possible. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. For the latest weather information visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification Title: Planned Closure - Hunter's Point Avenue Bridge (QN)
Email Body:
Notification issued 3/27/16 at 3:00 PM. As part of the emergency restoration from Superstorm Sandy damage, the NYC Department of Transportation will fully close the Hunter's Point Avenue Bridge over Newtown Creek on five consecutive days from Monday, March 28th, through Friday, April 1st. The closures will take place from 9:00 AM to 3:00 PM each day and affect vehicular, pedestrian, and bicycle traffic. Detour signs will be posted to assist motorists around the closure.

For detour information, please visit: http://i.imgur.com/L8Zhepb.jpg.

Notification Title: Travel Advisory & Alternate Side Parking Suspension (CW)
Email Body:
Notification issued 3/20/16 at 7:35 PM. New Yorkers are reminded that a travel advisory is in effect from Sunday evening through Monday morning, March 21, and Alternate Side Parking is suspended on Monday. According to forecasts, snow is expected to begin around 9:00 PM, Sunday, and will end by daybreak Monday, with the a chance of lingering snow showers through the morning commute. A total snow accumulation of two to four inches is anticipated. Nighttime temperatures Sunday are expected to be around freezing. New Yorkers are asked to exercise caution and be prepared for slippery roads. As nighttime temperatures drop to below freezing, untreated surfaces can cause slick conditions. Please allow for extra travel time during your commutes.

ASL: http://bit.ly/11wDLan

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.
Notification issued 3/20/16 at 2:32 AM. Following an earlier suspension, the 2 and 3 train have resumed service and are temporarily bypassing 135th Street. Expect residual delays.

Notification issued 3/20/16 at 12:38 AM. Due to a customer injury, 3 train service is suspended between 148th Street and 96th Street in both directions in Manhattan. The 2 train is currently running on the 5 line. Consider alternate routes and allow for additional travel time.

Notification issued 03/19/16 at 3:00 PM. Numerous rolling street closures will be in effect throughout Manhattan from 7:30 AM to 1:00 PM on Sunday, 03/20/16, in support of the 2016 New York Road Runners' NYC Half Marathon. Consider use of public transportation during this event. For more information, please visit http://www.nyrr.org/races-and-events/2016/united-airlines-nyc-half or see the route map at http://i.imgur.com/lAdEmQd.png.

Notification Title: Mayor De Blasio Issues Travel Advisory (CW)
Email Body:
Notification issued 3/18/16 at 9:23 PM. Mayor De Blasio has issued a travel advisory for Sunday, March 20, 2016. According to forecasts, snow may develop during the day on Sunday, with the potential for two to four inches of accumulation through early Monday morning. Daytime temperatures Sunday are expected to be in the mid-30s and will drop to near freezing Sunday night. New Yorkers are asked to exercise caution and be prepared for slippery roads. As nighttime temperatures drop to below freezing, untreated surfaces can cause slick conditions. Please allow for extra travel time during your commutes.

ASL: http://bit.ly/11wC2C0

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 3/18/16 at 4:09 PM. New York City is experiencing intermittent wind gusts in excess of 40 MPH. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. For the latest weather information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 3/14/16 at 9:00 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Coastal Flood Statement for Brooklyn and Staten Island which is in effect tonight from 1:00 AM to 3:00 AM, March 15th, 2016. The affected area includes the south shore back bays of Brooklyn and Staten Island. Tidal departures of 1 to 2 feet above normal are expected.

During a coastal flood event, minor flooding of the most vulnerable shore roads and/or adjacent properties is possible due to the height of the storm tide, wave splash-over, and/or effects of the full moon.

For the latest information please visit: www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 3/14/16 at 5:00 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Coastal Flood Advisory for Southern Queens which is in effect tonight from 1:00 AM to 3:00 AM, March 15, 2016. The affected area includes the south shore back bays of Nassau and Queens. Tidal departures around 2 feet above normal are possible. 

During a Coastal Flood Advisory, minor flooding of the most vulnerable shore roads and/or properties is possible. Coastal residents should be alert for later statements and take action to protect property.

For more information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Email Body: Alert issued 3/12/16 at 6:41 PM. The previously issued AMBER Alert for Ariel Revello has been canceled.

Notification Title: AMBER Alert - Ariel Revello M/H/7 (Trumbull, CT)
Email Body:
AMBER Alert issued 3/12/16 at 12:25 PM.

The NY State Police has issued an AMBER Alert for the abduction of Ariel Revello, a 7-year-old Hispanic male from Connecticut. The child may be in imminent danger.

He is described as being 4' 8'' tall and 75lbs with brown hair and brown eyes. He was last seen at approximately 4:40 AM on 3/12 wearing gray and blue pajamas, gray sweatshirt, olive green puffy jacket and blue croc shoes. 

He was reportedly abducted in the area of Trumbull, CT, by the suspect, Rodolfo Revello, a 43-year-old bald Hispanic male with brown eyes. He is approximately 5'9'' tall and 190lbs.

They may be operating a white Ford transit van with CT license plate number C040379. The suspect is believed to be heading to the New York City area, specifically The Bronx.

A photo of the child is available at http://i.imgur.com/XxcyjAL.jpg. If you see Ariel or Rodolfo, call the Trumbull Police Department at (866) NYS-AMBER or call 9-1-1. 
For updates: http://amber.ny.gov.

Notification issued 3/6/16 at 3:00 PM. Beginning tomorrow, Monday, March 7, 2016, the Manhattan-bound (north) tube of the Queens Midtown Tunnel will be closed during weeknights for approximately 18 months to accommodate Superstorm Sandy restoration work. One lane will remain open in each direction in the other tube during these periods. Closures will take place between 10:30 p.m. and 5:30 a.m., Monday through Thursday. On Fridays, the closures will take place from 11 p.m. to 8 a.m. Saturday. Traffic enforcement agents and signage will help direct motorists, who should allow extra time and may wish to use an alternate route if possible. Info: http://bit.ly/1XXYtXO.

Expect smoke, traffic delays, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

Notification Title: Planned Closure - Grand Street Bridge - March 5, 12 & 19 (BK/QN)
Email Body: Notification issued 3/4/16 at 3:00 PM. The NYC Department of Transportation Division of Bridges will close the Grand Street Bridge over Newtown Creek during the day on three Saturdays for repairs. The bridge will be closed to vehicles in both directions between 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. on March 5, 12, and 19. Variable message signs will be installed to alert motorists. Metropolitan Avenue may be used as an alternative route. The bridge will remain open to pedestrians and cyclists, but cyclists may be required to dismount and follow the directions of the work crews. Variable message signs will be installed to alert motorists. For more information, please visit http://i.imgur.com/RGpdlnL.jpg.

From 10:00 PM on Friday, March 4, through 6:00 AM on Saturday, March 5, the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, in conjunction with multiple agencies, will conduct an Environmental Sampling Exercise beginning at NYC Public Health Laboratory at 455 First Avenue in Manhattan, then continuing at Grand Central Terminal, Manhattan. Environmental Sampling Teams will be in personal protective equipment, including full hazmat suits. Expect a heightened presence of emergency personnel in the area. No biological material is being released and there is no danger to the public. This is only a drill.

Notification issued 2/24/16 at 10:30 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for NYC until 11:30 PM. Strong winds and heavy rain are expected. 

Info: http://www.weather.gov/nyc. 

During a severe thunderstorm, be prepared to potentially lose power. Charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by the outage, turn off all appliances, avoid downed and hanging power lines, and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. 

To view this message in American Sign Language (ASL) with audio and subtitles, please visit: http://bit.ly/1t08zHb.

Notification issued 2/24/16 at 7:50 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Watch for NYC until 2:00 AM on 2/25. Strong winds and heavy rain are possible.

A Severe Thunderstorm Watch means conditions are favorable for severe thunderstorms to occur in and close to the watch area. Persons within these areas should be on the lookout for threatening weather conditions and listen for later statements and possible warnings. Exercise caution when walking, driving, or biking. 

Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. Notification Title: Staten Island Ferry & Railway - Service Changes and Suspension (SI)
Email Body:
Notification issued 2/24/16 at 6:13 PM. Due to NYPD activity, Staten Island Ferry's St. George Terminal will be closed to passengers until further notice. All outbound service from St. George is suspended. Service out of Whitehall is operating on a normal schedule, but passengers will be exiting via the lower level in St. George.

Staten Island Railway service is suspended between St. George & Tompkinsville in both directions. Please consider alternate routes and allow for additional travel time. www.mta.info.

Notification issued 2/24/16 at 3:30 PM.  The NYC Department of Transportation will be closing the Metropolitan Avenue Bridge over English Kills in the early morning on 5 days, February 25 - February 27, February 29, and March 1, 2016, to continue the rehabilitation of the bridge from damage due to Superstorm Sandy. 

The full closure will take place Thursday and Friday from 12:01 AM to 5:00 AM, Saturday from 1:00 AM to 6:00 AM, and Monday and Tuesday from 12:01 AM to 5:00 AM. The closures impact vehicular, pedestrian and bicycle traffic including the Q54 Metropolitan Avenue bus. Detour signs will be posted to assist motorists around the closure and there will be Traffic Control Agents posted each night from 11:30 PM until 6:30 AM. 

For more information please visit www.facebook.com/MetroSandyBridge or http://i.imgur.com/TpPtNFF.jpg.

Notification issued 2/24/16 at 2:20 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Wind Advisory for New York City in effect from 2/24 6:00 PM to 2/25 4:00 AM. The advisory has been issued for sustained winds of 25 - 35 MPH with gusts between 45 - 50 MPH. 

Department of Buildings advises property owners, crane operators & contractors to take precautionary measures in preparation for the high winds. All cranes must be secured.

During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. Notification issued 2/24/16 at 10:00 AM. The U.S. Department of Homeland Securitys Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), in coordination with state, local, tribal, and territorial emergency managers and state broadcasters associations, will conduct a test of the Emergency Alert System (EAS) in New York City today, February 24, at 2:20 pm.  

The EAS test is made available to radio, broadcast and cable television systems is and scheduled to last approximately one minute. The test will verify the delivery and broadcast, and assess the readiness for distribution of a national-level test message. The message of the test will be similar to the regular monthly test message of EAS, normally heard and seen by the public: This is a national test of the Emergency Alert System. This is only a test.

More information on the Public Alert and Warning System and Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA) is available at www.fema.gov/ipaws or www.ready.gov/alerts.

Notification issued 2/16/16 at 2:52 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for The Bronx, Brooklyn, and Queens until 3:15 PM. Strong winds and heavy rain are expected. Info: http://www.weather.gov/nyc. During a severe thunderstorm, be prepared to potentially lose power. Charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by the outage, turn off all appliances, avoid downed and hanging power lines, and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. To view this message in American Sign Language (ASL) with audio and subtitles, please visit: http://bit.ly/1t08zHb.

Notification Title: 3 Alarm Fire - Olmstead Avenue & Ellis Avenue (BX)
Email Body: Notification issued 2/15/16 at 6:20 AM. Emergency personnel are on the scene of a three alarm fire located at Olmstead Avenue and Ellis Avenue in The Bronx. Expect smoke, traffic delays, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

The National Weather Service has issued a Winter Weather Advisory for the NYC area on 2/15 from 1:00PM to midnight. A total of 1-4'' of snow, a trace of ice, and 1.25''-1.5'' of rain are predicted through the event. Light snow is expected to begin Monday morning and is forecast to transition to freezing rain Monday evening. Freezing rain is then expected to change over around midnight to rain only, which will continue throughout the day on Tuesday, resulting in minor coastal flooding during high tide cycles. Sustained winds of 20-25mph and gusts up to 30-40mph are also possible Tuesday.
 
New Yorkers are advised to exercise caution when driving, walking, or biking, and allow for additional travel time as roads may be slippery and visibilities may be low.

Notification issued 2/12/16 at 6:40 PM. Winds are forecast to gust up to 45 mph in the New York City area beginning tomorrow, Saturday, February 13th and continuing through the evening of Sunday, February 14th. Department of Buildings advises property owners, crane operators & contractors to take precautionary measures in preparation for the high winds. All cranes must be secured. 

In addition, the Department has required all crane operations to cease on Saturday. A limited resumption of crane activity may be allowed on Sunday, depending on wind speeds. Crane operators are required to closely monitor weather conditions beginning Friday afternoon.

The Department will be performing random spot-check inspections of construction sites around the City. If sites are not secured, the Department will take immediate enforcement action -- issuing violations and Stop Work Orders, where necessary.
 
Winds may reach higher speeds than forecast in certain areas of the City. Property owners must consider the safety

The National Weather Service has issued a Wind Chill Advisory in effect from 4:00 PM Saturday through noon on Sunday for expected wind chills as low as 20 to 25 degrees below zero. New Yorkers are urged to limit their time outdoors and report heat and hot water conditions to property managers & 3-1-1. Remember to keep your pets safe, and check in on vulnerable friends, relatives and neighbors, including the elderly and people with disabilities and access and functional needs. 

For more information: http://on.nyc.gov/1TdyZoB

Notification Title: NYC Emergency Management Cold Weather Alert (CW)
Email Body:
Notification issued 2/10/16 at 6:05 PM. New York City Emergency Management urges New Yorkers to prepare for extremely cold temperatures Thursday night, February 11 through Monday, February 15. High temperatures Thursday will be at or below freezing. Temperatures drop to the teens Thursday night, with wind chill values in the single digits. Daytime temperatures are forecast to stay below freezing Friday, and continue to drop Friday night into Saturday, with temperatures in the teens and wind chill values near zero. Saturday night temperatures drop to single digits, and wind chill values are expected to plummet to as low as 15 degrees below zero. Wind chill values are expected to remain below zero through Sunday morning, slightly increasing to single digits Sunday night through early Monday morning. Temperatures should begin to moderate Monday afternoon, with highs expected to be around freezing through Monday night. 

New Yorkers are advised to check on their neighbors, friends, and relatives, especially the

Notification issued 2/9/16 at 8:15 PM. Mayor de Blasio has issued a travel advisory for Wednesday, February 10, and reminds New Yorkers to remain alert and aware of cold temperatures and slippery conditions.

The National Weather Service has issued a Winter Weather Advisory from 6:00 PM tonight through noon on Wednesday for an expected 2-4 inches of snow. Light snow is expected to begin this evening and will continue through tomorrow morning, with the heaviest snow falling overnight. With overnight temperatures at or below freezing, and daytime temperatures in the high 30s, the potential exists for slick road conditions and limited visibilities.

Please exercise caution when driving, walking, or biking, and allow for extra travel time during the morning and evening commutes.

For more information, please visit: http://on.nyc.gov/1PjNViB.

For more information, visit www.mta.info.

Notification issued 2/9/16 at 4:45 PM. The National Weather Service has issued a Coastal Flood Advisory for shore locations of Brooklyn, southern Queens, and Staten Island for high tide tonight and tomorrow morning, 2/10.

The Coastal Flood Advisory is in effect from 8PM to midnight tonight, with tides expected to be 1.5 feet to 2.5 feet above normal, and from 7AM to 12PM tomorrow, 2/10, for tides of 1-2 feet above normal.

During a Coastal Flood Advisory, minor flooding of the most vulnerable shore roads and/or properties is possible. Coastal residents should be alert for later statements and take action to protect property.

For more information, visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification issued 2/9/16 at 11:47 AM. The National Weather Service has issued a Winter Weather Advisory from 6PM tonight until noon Wednesday. A total of 3 - 5 inches of snow is expected accompanied by below freezing temperatures. 

New Yorkers are asked to exercise caution when driving and allow for additional travel time, as roads may be slippery.

Notification issued 2/8/16 at 6:00 PM. The National Weather Service has issued the following coastal flood products for high tides tonight, 2/8, and tomorrow morning, 2/9. Tidal departures are expected to be 2 to 2.5 feet above normal.
 
South Queens: Coastal Flood Warning in effect 2/8 from 7PM-11PM and 2/9 from 7AM-11PM for areas along southern shores.

Brooklyn: Coastal Flood Warning in effect until 11 PM tonight, and 2/9 from 7AM-11AM for areas along southern shores.

During a Coastal Flood Warning, widespread moderate flooding is expected, resulting in beach erosion and flooding of vulnerable shore roads and/or properties. Coastal residents in the warned area should be alert for rising water and take appropriate action to protect life and property.

Bronx: Coastal Flood Advisory in effect 2/9 from 9AM-1PM for areas along Long Island Sound.

Staten Island: Coastal Flood Advisory in effect until 11PM tonight, and 2/9 from 7AM-10AM for areas along Newark Bay, The Kills, & tidally affected portions

Notification Title: NYC Emergency Management Issues Travel Advisory (CW)
Email Body:
Notification issued at 2/4/16 at 7:48 PM. The New York City Emergency Management Department today issued a travel advisory for Friday, February 5, 2016. The National Weather Service has issued a Winter Weather Advisory from 1:00 AM through 10:00 AM Friday. Rain is expected to begin around 7:00 PM Thursday and will change over to snow around 3:00 AM Friday. Snow will continue through the early morning commute and will taper off around 10:00 AM. A total snow accumulation of 2-4 inches is predicted, with the heaviest snow expected to fall between 3:00 AM and 9:00 AM Friday. Temperatures Thursday night are forecast to be at or below freezing. Daytime temperatures Friday will be in the low 40s, but nighttime temperatures will drop to the high 20s, creating the potential for slick road conditions. New Yorkers are asked to exercise caution and be prepared for limited visibility and slippery road conditions. Please allow for extra travel time during the morning and evening commutes. 

For more information and safet

Notification issued 2/3/16 at 9:25 PM. New York City is experiencing intermittent wind gusts in excess of 40 MPH. During periods of high winds, residents should use caution when walking or driving high profile vehicles. Winds at these speeds can cause flying debris, turn unsecured objects into projectiles, and cause power outages. To prepare, charge cell phone batteries, gather supplies, and turn refrigerators and freezers to a colder setting. Always stay clear of downed power lines. If you are affected by an outage, turn off all appliances and keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to prevent food spoilage. Do not use generators indoors. If you lose power and have a disability or access needs, or use Life Sustaining Equipment (LSE) and need immediate assistance, please dial 9-1-1. For the latest weather information, please visit www.weather.gov/nyc.

Notification Title: Three Alarm Fire - West 100th St & Broadway (MN)
Email Body: Notification issued 2/2/16 at 11:18 AM. Emergency personnel are on the scene of a three alarm fire located near West 100th Street and Broadway in Manhattan. Expect smoke, traffic delays, and a presence of emergency personnel and vehicles in the area. The NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene advises avoiding smoke exposure from structural fires by closing windows while indoors and reducing outdoor activity where smoke is present. People with heart or breathing conditions such as asthma may be more sensitive and should seek immediate medical attention if they experience a worsening of their condition, shortness of breath, or chest pains.

Ms. Devonish was last seen at approximately 9:12 AM on 2/1 wearing a dark blue jacket, a blue turtle neck sweater, an orange shirt, grey slacks, and grey sneakers. A photo of the missing is available at http://i.imgur.com/FSB0a9C.png?1. If you see Madeline Devonish, please call 9-1-1.
